analytic.title: A Markov Random Field Model-Based Approach to Unsupervised Texture Segmentation Using Local and Global Spatial Statistics

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Absfract
div.p: -Many studies have proven that statistical model-based texture segmentation algorithms yield good results provided that the model parameters and the number of regions be known a priori. In this correspondence, we present an Unsupervised texture segmentation method that does not require knowledge about the Merent texture regions, their parameters, or the number of available texture classes. The proposed algorithm relies on the analysis of local and global second and higher order spatial statistics of the original images. The segmentation map is modeled using an augmented-state Markov random field, including an outlier class that enables dynamic creation of new regions during the optimization process. A Bayesian estimate of this map is computed using a deterministic relaxation algorithm. Results on real-world textured images are presented.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: unsupervised image segmentation remains a fundamental issue in low-level image analysis and computer vision since most high-level processing schemes must rely on reliable and robust segmentations. In this correspondence, we address the problem of nonsupervised texture segmentation. Although this problem has received considerable attention in the last decade 141,181, [lo], [ll], [13], completely data-driven segmentation methods, able to handle real-world textured images, remain beyond the present state-of-the-art. The algorithm presented in this correspondence is unsupervised in the following sense:

it does not require a priori knowledge on the textures of the image (in particular no learning step is necessary); the number of regions or texture classes needs not to be known either. Early attempts at nonsupervised texture segmentation have made use of texture measures associated with edge detection techniques [8]. A more powerful approach consists in modeling the different textures with stationary statistical models, for instance Gauss-Markov random fields (GMRF) [lo]- [12]. The image is usually divided into disjoint local windows [lo]- [12]. Each region is assumed to contain mainly one texture. This assumption enables one to identify locally the parameters of stationary texture models [ll], [12]. Windows with nearby parameters are then merged using clustering techniques [IO], [12]. One problem with these methods is the difficulty of the computation, from local windows, of reliable parameters for the underlying model. Several authors [4], [7] have $us proposed describing texture using statistical features [6] that are computed in local windows. The use of local texture features, instead of global texture models, reduces significantly the number of parameters to be determined.

An intricate issue for these different approaches is the determination of the number of textures present in the image. Model fitting criteria have been proposed recently to address this problem [13].

In this correspondence, we propose an alternate approach relying on an augmented state-MRF model that enables one to handle an a priori unknown number of regions'. Our model is inspired by the model described by Geman et al., in [4], with several significant differences. In [4], various texture features are used, along with an MRF model of the segmentation map. The algorithm is partially unsupervised but the number of regions is assumed to be known approximately and thresholds for discriminating the different textures have to be fine-tuned. In the approach proposed here, the segmentation is obtained using a deterministic relaxation procedure that simultaneously determines the current number of regions. This is achieved by introducing an additional state (corresponding to an outlier class) in the MRF model representing the image partition. This additional label enables the dynamic creation of new regions during the relaxation process (a similar idea has been suggested for motion-based segmentation by Bouthemy and FranGois [2]). Mixed windows may thus be split in several sub-regions, leading to reliable and robust parameter estimation. Besides, the method only q u i r e s the tuning of one parameter, which is a probability that determines all the thresholds on the texture features. div.p: Defining global energy functions is a powerful tool for specifying nonlinear interactions between different image features (luminance, edges, region labels, etc.). They help to combine and organize spatial and temporal information by introducing strong generic knowledge about the features to be estimated. Energy minimization techniques have been used in a wide range of applications including image restoration, edge detection, luminance and texture segmentation, surface reconstruction, visual motion analysis, and scene interpretation [3]. The choice of particular energy functions is either heuristic or may be guided by a statistical modeling of the interaction between the variables, as will be seen in the following.

div.head: A. Statistical Texture Features
div.p: The observations, on which the segmentation process is based, correspond to vectors of texture features describing various spatial statistics. These features are computed on local windows and are assigned to the pixel located at the center of the window. To each site is thus assigned a feature vector os = [ ~' ( s ) , . . . , om(s)] where oa (s), i = 1, . . . , m designates the ith texture feature computed at site s and m is the number of texture features. The features that have been used here include seven features proposed by Haralick (mean, variance, energy, correlation, entropy, contrast, and homogeneity), derived from the joint occurrency matrices [6] and three other features proposed by Geman et aL, [4] (the gray level, the local contrast, and an "isotropic residual"). div.head: C. The Relaxation Algorithm
div.p: To minimize the global energy function, stochastic relaxation [5] has not been considered since it is too expensive from a computational point of view. We have adopted a modified version of the standard deterministic ICM algorithm [l], which alternately updates the segmentation map e and the current number of regions.

Let us denote by R the current number of regions. The candjdate region labels for a given site s are thus labels r = 1, . . . , R. In the standard ICM algorithm [l], the label that produces the largest decrease of the energy function is selected to update site s. This amounts to the minimization of a local energy function that is derived from the global energy U by computing the energy variation induced by updating the site s [l], [5]. For the initialization of the process, an initial value of R = 1 is used, which corresponds to one single region in the image. This initial single region is updated using a maximum likelihood estimator of the label field, which is nothing but the minimization of the global energy without the prior term U2 [7]. The current number of regions R is updated once the relaxation on the label field e has converged. At the end of each relaxation stage (i.e., when the label field is stable),

the connected components of the outlier class (i.e., the pixels labeled p ) are relabeled with new region numbers (Fig. 2). However, label p is maintained for all small connected components (of size less than 1% of the image size). These points will not be considered for the computation of global region characteristics, but may be visited and relabeled in the next relaxation step. This procedure allows a small region to grow until it reaches a size sufficient for providing significant statistics. The global statistical distributions associated with each significant region are updated after the relabeling process. This relaxation-relabeling process is pursued until stability is obtained on the label field. The number of iterations required to reach stability depends on the complexity of the scene. However, in practice, the process has been stopped after three complete relaxation-relabeling procedures with satisfactory results.

div.head: IV. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
div.p: The segmentation technique described in the previous section has been applied to different mosaics composed of natural textures extracted from the Brodatz album, as well as on real-world textured images. Experimental results on images used in other references are presented to make the comparison with other approaches easier. Other results are reported in 171.

The features related to the joint occurrency matrices were computed on 16 gray-level images in 5 x 5 local windows, along four directions with a distance d = 3 (d = 2 yielded similar results). The other parameters (gray levels, contrast, and directional residuals) were computed on a 15 x 15 window. Parameter p was set to 1.5, which corresponds to a good balance between the a priori energy U2 and the data term U1 . The only parameter that needed to be tuned was parameter p [defined by (7)], which determines the different thresholds on the texture features. The results turned out to be largely insensitive to the adjustment of parameter p (the "optimal" value could be modified by 10% without noticeable changes in the segmentation: results obtained for different values of parameter p are presented in [7]). The CPU time, on a S u n 4 station, reached about 25 mn, for 128 x 128 images.

We first describe the results obtained on various texture mosaics, including different textures and object geometry. Fig. 3(a) presents the first mosaic, which is composed of three different textures. Fig. 3(b) shows the boundary of the underlying mosaic, which corresponds to the ground truth. The boundaries of the final segmentation are superimposed on the original image in Fig. 3(c). The error between the ground truth and the segmentation obtained by the unsupervised method is depicted Fig. 3(d). Three regions are obtained in this case for a value p = 0.75. The boundaries of the different regions are delineated quite accurately, even if the MRF prior tends to "smooth" the region boundary in high curvature areas. Similar qualitative results have been obtained on several other handassembled images corresponding to different mosaic patterns. Fig. 4 reproduces a mosaic pattem close to the one used in the reference [4] (by Geman et al). A second typical mosaic, borrowed from [lo] (in which a MRF model is used for representing textures), is shown in Fig. 5. As can be seen, our result are qualitatively close to the one reported in [4] and [lo].

The processing of red-world (textured) images is generally more involved, mainly because the textures appearing in natural images are usually nonstationary. We present results of segmentation on three real-world images that have been selected for their representativity and their difficulty. The images show several textured regions with various (possibly nonstationary) spatial statistics (Figs. 678). Artifacts or nonstationary areas in textures are difficult to handle and lead generally to over-segmented images if they are not taken into account in the model. The approach proposed here, although using stationary texture models, seems quite robust to these phenomena, as will be seen. Fig. 6 corresponds to an aerial image showing two cultivated fields: the boundary between the two regions is delineated quite accurately, although the upper region is not homogeneous. Fig. 7 presents another aerial image. This kind of image is typical of realworld applications, in which the textures are nonhomogeneous and where the number of regions is difficult to determine, even visually. In this case four significant regions are obtained: in particular, the forest area has been segmented in two regions, with different spatial patterns. The two other regions are cultivated fields. Fig. 8 shows a satellite image of the south-eastem part of France, with similar difficulties. The area includes a part of the Alps and a part of the Mediterranean Sea. Even on this hard example (which shows highly nonstationary textures), a relevant segmentation (Fig. 8(b)) is obtained. The algorithm enables one to separate quite accurately the different significant areas: mountain, land, and sea. data-driven segmentation algorithm. The proposed approach does not require training on the textures to be partitioned. The number of regions in the image need not to be known either. The method makes use of local and global spatial statistics within a global statistical estimation framework relying on Markov random field models. The method only requires the tuning of one parameter that determines the thresholds on the different texture features. Several examples have shown the capability of the model to yield usable segmentations on hand-assembled images consisting of natural textures as well as on complex real-world textured images.
